task.title: Using CVS with and
task.shortdesc: This topic shows you how to perform common tasks using with and a traditional software configuration management (SCM) system.

taskbody.prereq:
As a best practice, it is recommended that you store the project content in the following way:
Store only the default projects and minimum artifacts required for collaboration in .
Store non-default projects separately in the SCM system, not in .
Store implementation content in the unshared and unmirrored library modules in the SCM system. It is also recommended that you understand these and other best practices of sharing projects between and that are described in the following articles:
Best practices when using IBM Integration Designer and IBM Process Designer together.
Develop Advanced Integration services for IBM Business Process Manager V8.5.6.

context.p:
If you are using with , you are either storing your projects in or storing them in both and an SCM system. The latter case is likely to apply if you were working with earlier versions of WebSphere Integration Developer for several reasons:
The SCM contains a history that is important for maintaining code integrity.
There are usually automated build scripts that run from the SCM.
Corporate standards may require that you continue to use a specific SCM. Working with two repositories introduces additional complexity to the governance system, but those can be addressed by careful planning. These instructions will help you manage that configuration successfully.

Although this topic addresses working with Concurrent Versions System (CVS), the principles also apply to other SCM systems. For more information about working with CVS or other SCM systems, see the related links at the end of this topic. You can access actions for source control management system clients that you have currently installed from the Business Integration view by right clicking a project and opening the Team menu.

Eclipse only allows one SCM to be associated with a project. If you use with another SCM system, treat as a secondary repository. The SCM system is the primary storage area used by the developers as they work with their artifacts. Load projects to the intermittently, perhaps at project milestones. Do not check projects out from to make changes.
Because you work from CVS, artifacts such as business process definitions, which are solely associated with will not exist in the CVS repository.

step.info: A project that is under CVS control can be added to by associating it with a process application or toolkit (see the related links for instructions). That association creates a bpm.repo.prefs file in the .settings folder. That file contains the details about the association. checks for this file when a when a project is brought into a workspace. If finds that file, it will connect to the repository and show the project as contained in the specified process application or toolkit. You can add a project to the repositories in either order, but if you associate the project with last, synchronize the project with CVS immediately after association so that the bpm.repo.prefs file is visible if someone checks the file out of CVS.

step.cmd: Remove projects from the by disassociating them.
step.info: You need access authority on the to perform this task.

substep.cmd: In the Business Integration view of , right click the project and select Disassociate from Process Center.
substep.info: Disassociation removes the project from the Process Center repository and deletes the bpm.repo.prefs file. The file will still exist in previous snapshots, so a disassociation can be reversed.

substep.cmd: Synchronize with CVS immediately so the disassociation is registered there before someone else checks out the file.

step.cmd: Check out files only from CVS, using the CVS Import wizard or the CVS navigator.
step.info: Although makes it easy to bring in projects from using the pop-up menu, you should not do that for projects that reside in CVS. CVS metadata is stripped out when a project is shared with the repository. If you pull projects from , the files will not be connected to CVS. If you unintentionally make changes to files that you have accessed in this way, you need to publish them to and have someone pull them into another workspace that still contains the CVS connection for the project. The revised project can then be committed to CVS from there.

step.cmd: Before publishing projects to , update from CVS to capture any changes that have been made by the team. Immediately after publishing, synchronize with CVS.
step.stepresult: Doing these two actions keeps CVS as the system of reference and avoids conflicts between the two repositories.

step.cmd: Create tracks in before creating branches in CVS. Make the branch and track names similar so the relationship between them is easy to identify.

substep.cmd: In the Process Center perspective, select a process application.
In the process application title bar, select Manage. Select Allow users to create tracks in this process app.
Select Snapshots and then select an existing snapshot or create one. Click New Track: Screen capture showing the locations of the Snapshots and New Track controls.
substep.info: You need to create the track from a snapshot.

substep.cmd: In the Create New Track window, provide a name and description for the track. Click Create.
substep.stepresult: Now that a track exists in , you can create a corresponding branch in CVS.

substep.cmd: Right-click a project in CVS and select TeamBranch.
In the Create a new CVS branch window, give the branch a name and version.

At this point, the new CVS branch still points to the main track, not the new track. To complete the process, you need to replace the workspace content with the new track content. In the Business Integration view, right-click the project and select Replace WithLatest from Tip of Track .
Select the new track and click OK.
substep.stepresult: At this point, edits the bpm.repo.prefs file to point to the new track. However, the projects must still be reassociated with the new CVS branch.

substep.cmd: In the Business Integration view, select TeamShare Project .
In the Share Project window, select Use an existing module and select the module that you have associated with the process application.
substep.stepresult: The program recognizes that there is now a branch for that module and provides a page where you can choose to synchronize with the branch instead of the HEAD stream.

substep.cmd: Select the branch and click Next. If you do not see your branch, click Refresh Tags.
Expand the module settings, right-click bpm.repo.prefs, and select Mark as Merged. Select Launch the Commit wizard and click Next.
Right-click bpm.repo.prefs, and select Commit. Click Finish.

step.cmd: If a machine URL changes, edit the bpm.repo.prefs file to reflect the change.

If a project in CVS is associated with a that is no longer running, disassociate the project from the server. Right-click the project in the Business Integration view. Select Disassociate and confirm the action.
